school/math/linear-algebra/1.1-echelon-f.title: 1.1 Echelon Form
school/math/linear-algebra/1.1-echelon-f.description:
Definition 1.1.1 ((Row)Echelon Form). All non-zero rows are ontop
The start of a row is cascading down from the previous one
All entries in the column below are zeroes This essentially boils down to, zeros on the bottom, and the matrix forms a bottom left triangle of zeros
Definition 1.1.2 (Reduced (Row) Echelon Form).
Satisfies Echelon Form, and but the leading 1s in rows are the only values in their respective column
Uniqueness of Reduced Echelon form
Each matrix is row equivalent to just one echelon matrix.
Definition 1.1.3 (Pivot Position and Column).
The leading 1 in a reduced echelon form of A. Pivot column is a column of the matrix containing the pivot position
Definition 1.1.4 (Consistent Matrix).
At least one solution, or solutions

det(A) 0
Definition 1.5.2 (Nontrivial Solution).
det(A) 0
When working with economies, you're solving for a value you're setting equal to. Where each column corresponds to your take of the economy . We wanna optimize this, so you subtract from the diagonals (analogous to subtracting by identity). Thus to find our solution, you put your augmented matrix in the form

school/math/linear-algebra/1.9-the-matri.title: 1.9 The Matrix of a Linear Transformation
school/math/linear-algebra/1.9-the-matri.description: The goal of this subunit is to take a description of a linear transformation, and find it's mathematical representation.Theorem 1.9.1 (Linear Transformation from Identity). Let be a linear transformation, there exists a unique matrix A, such that if you have the transformations of each column of the identity matrix A is defined as Rationalizing this is easy, the identity matrix inherently would separate out the columns of the unknown matrix. Theorem 1.9.2 (Rotation Matrix). Given some desired rotation of points , the matrix A that describes that linear transformation is defined as This looks A LOT like the Unitary matricies , and the Quantum Gates THE GENERAL UNITARY MATRIX JUST INCLUDES COMPLEX ROTATIONS, OMG Specifically, the Unitary matrix is a rotation matrix for , preserving the L2 norm
school/math/linear-algebra/1.9-the-matri.sourcePath: School/Math/Linear Algebra/1.9 The Matrix of a Linear Transformation.md

school/math/linear-algebra/2.4-partition.title: 2.4 Partitioned Matrices and LU Factorization
school/math/linear-algebra/2.4-partition.description:
Matrices can be composed of different components, similar to Kronecker Tensor Products. We can wedge matrices together and there are rules on how to subsequently operate on them. Use1$$2\begin{array}{c|c}35 & 2 \\4\hline 53 & 46\end{array}7$$Definition 2.4.1 (Multiplication of Partitioned Matrices). A matrix and matrix can be multiplied together, if the columns of match the number of rows of , and if the partition of the columns in matches the partition of the rows in . Ex: Notably, if you use the partitions to separate the matrices into sub-blocks, and multiply them as scalars, the multiplication must obey regular matrix rules
Definition 2.4.2 (LU Factorization). Given a matrix , the LU factorization literally represents two matrices , and . represents the echelon formechelon form of , while L is a lower triangular matrix. Notice how both matrices are triangular? From this definition, given , we can then write it as . Then we make the substitution , giving us the following setup.By the above definition, L is square, and lower triangular. This makes calculating supremely easy as the matrix is invertible.Then given some values of y, we have our echelon form already so that we can solveNote that since U is already in echelon form, the pivot positions are 1, and thus the solution might be baked in.Definition 2.4.3 (LU Factorization Algorithm). First note that acts identically to , as it is simply the echelon form of . The only way for to transform space the same as given that already does that, is that if behaves identical to the identity matrix. Let's define an operator s.t applies the set of unique row operations transforming , seen below is defined such that applying those operations turns it into the identity matrix Note that because is a unique operator, for every , there is a distinct . is a linear operator. Also important to note that we can only make other linear combinations of rows, no scaling them onto themselves Example 2.4.4 (Find the LU factorization of matrix A). Now to obtain T, we would apply those operations in reverse to

school/math/linear-algebra/3.3-determina.description: As of writing, I know this topic incredibly well. It discusses Cramer's rule, cofactor expansions, and inverse's of matricesDefinition 3.3.1 (Adjunct). Inverse matrix before you scale down by the determinant. Shortcut to calculate is the inverse on calculator, and then scale up by the determinant. Transpose of coefficient matrix Definition 3.3.2 (Adjoin). Essentially the transpose in , but the Adjugate is the Hermitian

school/math/linear-algebra/4.2-subspaces.title: 4.2 Subspaces
school/math/linear-algebra/4.2-subspaces.description:
Overview This notes file will cover the idea of vectors and subspacesDefinition 4.2.1 (Column Space). Given a matrix , we define such that is composed of column vectors in . The column space is the subspace of which is defined by being a linear combination of the column vectors. It can be found by reducing into echelon formechelon form, then identifying the pivot columns. Those columns correspond to the column vectors in which are included in the span Definition 4.2.2 (Null Space). Given a matrix , the null space is the span of column vectors equal to zero.
To solve, just reduce to Reduced Row Echelon FormReduced Row Echelon Form, then the remaining solutions to are the vectors comprising your null space Definition 4.2.3 (Left Nullspace). Given a matrix , to find the left null space, you get the is the span of column vectors in , and set equal to zero.
To solve, just reduce to Reduced Row Echelon FormReduced Row Echelon Form, then the remaining solutions to are the vectors comprising your null space For a matrix , the column space is in , while the Null space is in If two matrices A and B are row equivalent, then their row spaces are the same. If B is in echelon form, the nonzero rows of B form a basis for the common row space.For any matrix, the row space dimension, agrees with the column space dimension
4.5 The Dimension of a Vector Space4.5 The Dimension of a Vector Space

school/math/linear-algebra/4.5-the-dimen.title: 4.5 The Dimension of a Vector Space
school/math/linear-algebra/4.5-the-dimen.description:
Definition 4.5.1 (Nullity).
The number of free variables in a matrix, or the dimension of the null space
Definition 4.5.2 (Rank).
The dimension of the column space
Properties Preserved under the transpose Theorem 4.5.3 (The Rank Theorem).
For an x matrix A, The above is basically saying, that the number of pivot columns (Rank), + the number of non-pivot columns (nullity) is equal to the number of columns
school/math/linear-algebra/4.5-the-dimen.sourcePath: School/Math/Linear Algebra/4.5 The Dimension of a Vector Space.md

school/math/linear-algebra/5.1-eigenvect.title: 5.1 Eigenvectors and Eigenvalues
school/math/linear-algebra/5.1-eigenvect.description: This notes document will review the definition, and ways to solve for eigenvectors and eigenvalues. Definition 5.1.1 (Eigenvectors). Given some square matrix , an eigenvector is a vector with a non-zero solution to the below equation Which is to say, when the transformation of a matrix is applied, the eigenvectors are the only parts of the space that are scaled linearly Definition 5.1.2 (Eigenvalues). Given some square matrix , an scalar , and a vector An eigenvalue is some quantity which satisfies , the conditions of , and the below equation ^5436ef You can find a quantum computing centered definition of eigenvalues here Definition 5.1.3 (Eigenbasis and Eigenspace). An eigenbasis is unique to a specific eigenvalue, which is the set of vectors which are solutions to the eigen-equation. The Eigenspace is the span of said eigenvectors To find an eigenvalue and eigenvector, firstTo get the eigenvalues, obtain the characteristic polynomial below, and solve for the roots, those are the eigenvaluesThen from here to get the eigenvectors, it's a matter of just solving for the unique solution to the eigen-equation.

school/math/linear-algebra/5.3-diagonali.title: 5.3 Diagonalization
school/math/linear-algebra/5.3-diagonali.description:
This note talks about the process of diagonalization, which utilizes 5.1 Eigenvectors and Eigenvalues5.1 Eigenvectors and Eigenvalues.All square matrices can be put into the form , where D is a diagonal matrixDefinition 5.3.1 (Diagonal Matrix). Any such square matrix which only has entries along the diagonal Remark 5.3.2 (Powers of Diagonal Matrix). Given a diagonal matrix , then the power of the matrix for This is actually why diagonal matrices can be so useful
Theorem 5.3.3 (Power of a Square Matrix). Using Definition 5.3.1Definition 5.3.1 and Remark 5.3.2Remark 5.3.2 , we can then make an expression for the general form of a matrix to a power. In general for Theorem 5.3.4 (The Diagonalization Theorem). An x matrix is only diagonalizable, if there are linearly independent eigenvectors.
With , is only possible if P is formed with the eigenvectorseigenvectors
of , and D has the eigenvalueseigenvalues along the diagonal, corresponding to the arrangement in
The nifty thing, is that this implies the eigenbasiseigenbasis spans First, find the eigenvectors. If there are unique eigenvectors, then we can complete the diagonalization Using the eigenvectors () as column vectors, form the matrix P Calculate the inverse of P
Then form D by placing the eigenvalues along the diagonal Fixing a Stupid Bug is actually finally relevant to this stuff Definition 2.4.1 (The Unitary Matrix). A single qubit matrix can be written with he three parameters in the form

school/math/linear-algebra/5.7-coupled-s.description: This details the formal process of solving coupled systems of equations if the coupling matrix contains distinct non-repeated eigenvalues.Theorem 5.7.1 (The Solution of a System of Differential Equations). Given a differential equation The solution is of the form Example 5.7.2 (Solving a coupled system of equations). Using matrix algebra techniques, find a general solution to the system. Solution First we put the system into the form Now we get the eigenvectors and eigenvalues solving of the matrix A by Finding the Eigenvalues and Eigenvectors In this case, the eigenvalues are and eigenvectors are From before, we know that our solution is the linear combination of these solutions. Thus, we get Example 5.7.3 (Solving the Initial Value Problem). Given that the system follows the form , with , and eigenvalues Find given Solution The general form of x(t) is Substituting in for , we then factor this into a eigenvector matrix, and an unknown matrix We can invert our eigenvector matrix, to then solve for our constants. Then we plug the values of back in for our final solution of To then decouple our system, we can write out the equationwhere This substitution is analogous to our same system, but now linearly oscillates

school/math/linear-algebra/6.3-orthogona.title: 6.3 Orthogonal and Orthonormal Spaces
school/math/linear-algebra/6.3-orthogona.description:
Referencing Orthonormal Bases../Quantum Computing/Semester 1/Definitions/Orthonormal Bases#^506716 could not be found. Definition 6.3.1 (Inner Product). Essentially the dot product. Given two vectors , the inner product of is Definition 6.3.2 (Orthogonal Subspaces). Two subspaces and of the same space are orthogonal, if every vector in is orthogonal to every vector in " w=0 for all and . Note a counter example, two planes in cannot be orthogonal subspaces. While one vector between them may be orthogonal, their intersection exists, and defines a vector. Theorem 6.3.3 (Fundamental theorem of Orthogonality). The row space is orthogonal to the nullspace in . The column space is orthogonal to the left nullspace in
Diagram from Gilbert Strang's "Essence of Linear Algebra" Theorem 6.3.4 (The Orthogonal Decomposition Theorem). Given some arbitrary vector and another vector , can be written in a new basis, formed by , and it's orthogonal pair. In math language, this says Where is the component of orthogonal to Given as a subspace of , any vector in can be written as a vector in , and in where is the component in , and is the component in . To define , we need the orthogonal basis of , . Then Finally, define a matrix such that it contains the normalized form of the orthogonal basis vectors as We can then find through arithmetic.
Theorem 6.3.5 (The Best Approximation Theorem). Given a vector , and a subspace of defined , the closest point to in is as defined in the Orthogonal Decomposition Theoremthe Orthogonal Decomposition Theorem What we're really doing here, is taking some line, defining an arbitrary perpendicular component, and using it to define a new basis for our vector .Useful trick for checking if a set of vectors is orthogonal: Given a set of vectors , we want to see if they are orthogonal without doing a recursive dot product (which has a complexity of . To do this, construct a matrix with the below property If is diagonal, then the vectors are orthogonal.
This works because the entry of is the dot product of . It should be zero everywhere we don't take a dot product where
school/math/linear-algebra/6.3-orthogona.sourcePath: School/Math/Linear Algebra/6.3 Orthogonal and Orthonormal Spaces.md

school/math/linear-algebra/6.4-gram-schm.title: 6.4 Gram-Schmidt Process
school/math/linear-algebra/6.4-gram-schm.description:
The Gram-Schmidt Process is an algorithm for producing an orthogonal or orthonormal basisorthonormal basis for a non-zero subspace of Definition 6.4.1 (Gram-Schmidt Process). The GS Process takes a set of vectors which span some subspace of , but are not orthogonal, and find the corresponding orthogonal basis for . This is useful if we only have vectors , and want to determine what is Instead of writing out the whole algorithm, here's some python code which does it using sympy 1def gs(x):2 # we define x as the matrix where vectors constructing the subspace are stored. x[:,0] is the first vector, x[:,1] is the second, etc.3 # for the gs process, we need to populate a new matrix which will contain our orthogonal basis4 w = sp.zeros(x.shape[0],x.shape[1])5 # the subspace w will be where we dump each subsequent projection6 for i in range(x.shape[1]):7 # if i == 0, we just want to dump the first vector into w, it is the trivial case8 if i == 0:9 w = x[:,i]10 else:11 # we want to project the ith vector of x onto the span of the previous vectors12 # add the projection as a new column to w, append it13 z = x[:,i]-proj(x[:,i],w)14 # Syntax of proj is vector to project, subspace to project onto15 # our goal is to add whatever is perpendicular to the previous vectors, so we subtract the projection and16 # insert it17 w=w.col_insert(i,z)18 return w
Definition 6.4.2 (QR Factorization). The utility of this factorization comes from two components of ^a227aaDefinition 6.4.1 (Gram-Schmidt Process) . We are given a set of non-orthogonal vectors, defined as columns of . Those vectors represent some subspace , which QR seeks to find the orthogonal basis of. The natural question to ask regarding , is what transformation converted into . Specifically Where is the matrix composed of the orthonormal (this is key, the vectors are normalized) basis of , and R is an upper triangular matrix with positive entries on the diagonal.
Because is composed of orthogonal vectors, , we can define with the below technique

school/math/linear-algebra/6.5-least-squ.title: 6.5 Least Squares and Linear Regression
school/math/linear-algebra/6.5-least-squ.description:
The Least Squares solution occurs if we are given an equation . but there is no solution for which makes the equation true. Then we want to approximate Given a matrix , a vector , and a vector , we might want to find a way to represent as a linear combination of the columns of . That is stated in the below equationThere are three possible outcomes to this equationWe already know if , there is either a unique solution for , or a whole subspace of solutions. But if isn't in the span, we might want to try and find some vector which when multiplied by is as close as you can get to . You can see a diagram example above, though in this case we're using instead of b, and represents the subspace defined by .We are essentially minimizing . (note that would be the resulting vector, being the weights for ).The square root operation is monotonic. minimizing is analogous to minimizing if .Explicitly, we're minimizing the belowThis is where we get the name, least squares.
From 6.3 Orthogonal and Orthonormal Spaces > ^585d01Theorem 6.3.5 (The Best Approximation Theorem), we know that the vector which minimizes the above statement, is .First we write out our definitionFor kicks, we're going to subtract from both sides
Here is where things get useful. Through The Orthogonal Decomposition TheoremThe Orthogonal Decomposition Theorem , we know , where . Essentially, is perpendicular to any space that resides in, which is .
From The Fundamental Theorem of OrthogonalityThe Fundamental Theorem of Orthogonality, we know that , or that the space perpendicular to the column space of , is the Left Null SpaceLeft Null Space.Through the properties of the null space, this impliesDefinition 6.5.1 (Least-Squares Solution). Given a matrix , a vector , and a vector , a least-squares solution of is an such that Theorem 6.5.2 (Normal Equations and Finding the Least-Squares Solution). The set of least-squares solutions of coincides with the non-empty set of solutions to the below equation. See proof above. If , then has a unique solution defined below Definition 6.5.3 (Least Squares Error). Given a least squares solution , the least squares error is That is to say, the minimal possible distance between the vector, and your prediction "The normal equations for a least-squares problem can be ill-conditioned; that is, small errors in the calculations of the entries of can sometimes
cause relatively large errors in the solution . If the columns of A are linearly independent, the least-squares solution can often be computed more reliably through a QR FactorizationQR Factorization of A"- Linear Algebra and It's Applications, Lay
To perform the above, we'd get the matrix composed of the orthonormal vectors in , then , or the closest vector to is by The Orthogonal Decomposition TheoremThe Orthogonal Decomposition Theorem. Then if , you either RREF if , or if ,
Definition 6.5.4 (Linear Regression Algorithm). Given a set of points , the goal is to find regression coefficients such that Note that correspond to in the standard linear equation. This can be expressed alternatively as Then you would use the \ref ^1ed15cTheorem 6.5.2 (Normal Equations and Finding the Least-Squares Solution) algorithm to solve, where ,

school/math/linear-algebra/7.1-quadratic.title: 7.1 Quadratic Forms and Orthogonal Matricies
school/math/linear-algebra/7.1-quadratic.description:
This file covers quadratic forms, which have logistical applications in many places. However, I don't know them and they weren't covered. #Question What are these good for?
^3bc9f8Definition 7.1.1 (Orthogonal Matrix)
Definition 7.1.1 (Orthogonal Matrix). A square matrix is orthogonal IFF This implies that the columns of A are orthogonalorthogonal Definition 7.1.2 (Symmetric Matrix). Given a matrix , a symmetric matrix is any matrix equal to it's transpose Definition 7.1.3 (Quadratic Form). A Q-form on is a function defined on whose value at is computed by Where A is an x symmetric matrix. The matrix A is called the matrix of the quadratic form The quadratic form will have cross product terms, which are any terms in the function . Essentially cross product terms Quadratic forms in have the form ofIf we are given and asked to find the matrix of the quadratic form, the matrix A takes the form
This is in part due to the fact that is symmetricsymmetric , which implies that we only need 3 pieces of information to constrain it(the off-diagonal must be equal). That information is given in the coefficients. Later, we should work through the whole proof.In general, the coefficients of will go along the diagonal. For any terms of the form , will be split in half against the coordinates of the matrix to keep the matrix symmetric.
Definition 7.1.4 (Change of Variable in Quadratic Form). Sometimes you may want to transform a quadratic formquadratic form and it's matrix, into a function of different variables without cross-product terms. In this case, we'd make the below substitution where is an invertible matrix, and . is the coordinate vector of relative to the basis of determined by
Applying this change of variables to gets us Because A is symmetric, there is guaranteed to be an orthogonal matrix P, which makes a diagonal matrix D by 5.3 Diagonalization > ^540799Theorem 5.3.4 (The Diagonalization Theorem)
More specifically, our unit eigenvectorseigenvectors of , and our associated eigenvalueseigenvalues .

info_showDefaultFolderIcons.description: Show a default icon of a folder for every folder in the tree

info_showDefaultFileIcons.description: Show a default icon of a file for every file in the tree

info_defaultFolderIcon.description: The icon to use for folders. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultFileIcon.description: The icon to use for files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_defaultMediaIcon.description: The icon to use for media files. Prefix with 'lucide//' to use a Lucide icon

info_exposeStartingPath.description: Whether or not to show the current file in the file tree when the page is first loaded

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_minCollapseDepth.description: Only allow outline items to be collapsed if they are at least this many levels deep in the tree.

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_displayTitle.description: Descriptive title to show above the feature

info_showOrphanNodes.description: Show nodes that are not connected to any other nodes.

info_showAttachments.description: Show attachments like images and PDFs as nodes in the graph.

info_allowGlobalGraph.description: Allow the user to view the global graph of all nodes.

info_allowExpand.description: Allow the user to pop-out the graph view to take up the whole screen

info_attractionForce.description: How much should linked nodes attract each other? This will make the graph appear more clustered.

info_linkLength.description: How long should the links between nodes be? The shorter the links the more connected nodes will cluster together.

info_repulsionForce.description: How much should nodes repel each other? This will make disconnected parts more spread out.

info_centralForce.description: How much should nodes be attracted to the center? This will make the graph appear more dense and circular.

info_edgePruning.description: Edges with a length above this threshold will not be rendered, however they will still contribute to the simulation. This can help large tangled graphs look more organised. Hovering over a node will still display these links.

info_minNodeRadius.description: How small should the smallest nodes be? The smaller a node is the less it will attract other nodes.

info_maxNodeRadius.description: How large should the largest nodes be? Nodes are sized by how many links they have. The larger a node is the more it will attract other nodes. This can be used to create a good grouping around the most important nodes.

info_allowResizing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be resized

info_allowCollapsing.description: Whether or not to allow the sidebars to be collapsed

info_rightDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the right sidebar

info_leftDefaultWidth.description: The default width of the left sidebar

info_selector.description: CSS selector for an element. The feature will be placed relative to this element.

info_type.description: Will this feature be placed before, after, or inside (at the beggining or end).

info_featurePlacement.description: Where to place this feature on the page. (Relative to the selector)

info_sourcePath.description: The local path to the source .html file which will be included.

info_allowFoldingLists.description: Whether or not to allow lists to be folded

info_allowFoldingHeadings.description: Whether or not to allow headings to be folded

info_siteUrl.description: The url that this site will be hosted at

info_authorName.description: The name of the author of the site
